column13: but we\'re getting the following from an strace. Didn\'t see the same behavior on 1.4.6. We have a large number of clients doing a \'reserve-with-timeout\'. Would that cause timestamp calls in a tight for-loop? epoll_wait(6

column10: b'b" This output looks normal. The process wakes up at least onceevery 10ms to see if anything needs to be done (such as movinga job from the delay queue to the ready queue). Beanstalkd used to compute the exact amount of time to wait
column11: so you\'d see absolutely no activity when nothing needs to bedone. I changed it to wake up at a fixed period while refactoringthe networking code and removing libevent
column12: because doing itthis way is easier to get right. Eventually I\'d like to switch backto an exact calculation of the sleep time
column13: but that\'s pretty fardown on the priority list
column14: since the performance impact is tiny
column15: and it only makes a difference when the system is idle."'

column10: b"b' custom upper limits on queue length?'"

b'b" It\'d be nice to have a size limit on queues specified by users. Do you have any plan to implement this? It\'ll be very sad if the job producers can keep feeding jobs into a queue until the queue server eventually runs out of memory."'
b'b" You can limit the total memory used by a beanstalkd processwith something like ulimit -v
column11: but there\'s no way to limitindividual tubes."'

column10: b'b" @agentzh Also
column11: running out of memory doesn\'t crash the process
column12: but simply makes producers unable to put new jobs until there is more available memory. See url  The only use-case I can see for your feature request is if you have multiple tubes and you would like to make sure that producers for one tube doesn\'t get blocked by producers filling up the beanstalkd instance with jobs in another tube. I\'d say this is a pretty rare case
column13: and you are making things overly complicated if this is an issue. @kr: I suggest this issue can be closed. @agentzh In case @kr closes this
column14: feel free to reopen if still an issue!"'

column10: b'b" This is a reasonable feature request
column11: but it has come up so rarely (and I\'m not aware of anyone who\'s actually had a problem because of the absence of this feature) that it\'s probably not worth adding."'

column10: b'b" @JensRantil For operating systems with memory over committing
column11: running out of memory may make the OOM killer engage in I\'m afraid. @kr The lack of the queue length limit still looks like a severe limitation to me. And from the implementor\'s perspective
column12: this should be dead simple to add IMHO."'

column10: b'b" Yeah
column11: I was probably too hasty in closing this bug. Sorry
column12: I did a bunch on an airplane and didn\'t consider this carefully. I still agree it\'s a reasonable feature request. Just know that I have no idea if I\'ll have the time to implement it in the near future. I\'d happily accept a patch for it. Perhaps a new command: that specifies either a number of jobs or a memory size in bytes (of the job payloads
column13: or perhaps including the internal job structs as well). @agentzh which of these would be more useful? Any tube with a specific limit would stick around. There would need to be a way to turn  the limit
column14: (e.g. or as special case). Of if you have a better suggestion for the interface

column11: but I have a process that seems to be reliably able to cause beanstalkd to segfault under linux.  My system is a Gentoo system with kernel 2.6.39-r3
column12: libevent 2.0.13
column13: and the latest version of beanstalkd from git (1.4.6+71+ge3158bc).  I use a python beanstalkc client for all of my connections
column14: but some of the connections are from python running under Windows XP and some are from python running under Linux.  The beanstalk server is running under Linux.  Almost all of the clients watch the same 5 tubes and dump their results into another queue.  I\'d be more than happy to provide more information if it would help. The segfault happens in prot.c at line 1531 - Looks like the reply is either unallocated or free\'d memory.  It may be something else entirely. I have a screenshot from a monitoring program I wrote.  If I could attach it to this report I would. It shows the number of jobs that are ready and reserved as well as the number of producers and workers for each tube.  Perhaps I can email it. I\'m not sure what I can do to help debug this problem
column15: but I\'m more than happy to help because I would love to have this fixed."'

column10: b"b' A second connection watching a tube hangs reserve-with-timeout'"
b'b\' When using reserve with timeout from multiple connections on the same tube
column11: only the last one receives "TIMED_OUT".  The other connections hang indefinitely.  This is occurs with the trunk codebase. More specifically:connection A watches tube \\\'foo\\\' then issues a reserve-with-timeout N secondsconnection B watches tube \\\'foo\\\' within the N seconds periodconnection A is never issued a "TIMED_OUT" response The issue seems to stem from the existing connection being removed from srv->conns when the most recent connection issues the watch foo command.  I\\\'m still digging into the code to understand why that is happening.\''

column10: b'b" This bug was introduced in a9d436718ad9d8c60a250dd0269feac5f1287a52. The problem is that when the client sends
column11: we currentlyask for an event when the client hangs up
column12: but don\'t actually closethe connection. As long as the connection remains open
column13: thishangup event is always available. Not only does this waste CPU
column14: it also effectively leaks an fd. I have a fix prepared
column15: once I get a chance to test the fix more
column16: I\'ll push it out. Probably tomorrow."'

column10: b'b\' I was never totally happy with the release process. I fiddled with it a few times and eventually settled on this. I had a couple of goals:  avoiding hard-coding the version number in source code in the main branch
column11: since that produces misleading output for every commit other than the actual release commit still having the release tarball contain the version string so it can build correctly (of course) being able to distribute the release directly from github using their tarball links  Making a little one-commit branch for each release let me do all of those things.  This all happened before github had a notion of releases
column12: so I\\\'m sure there is a better way now. Definitely feel free to change anything about this process if you want. I think github creates "releases" for tags automatically.  The only purpose of the dev* tags is to make it easy to know when releases happened on the main branch

column10: b"b'  For example
column11: uses the dev tags to print an accurate version string for whatever commit you happen to be on.'"
